annotation.TEXT: In 1967, Keith Moon, drummer for The Who, ran amuck at a Holiday Inn in Flint, MI, at his birthday party. Damages were $24K, and the Who were banned from Holiday Inns for life (lifted in 1999).
The original version of the “Goldilocks and the Three Bears” fairy tale featured an old woman instead of a young girl.
In The Flintstones episode “Ann-Margrock Presents,” Ann-Margret played a prehistoric version of herself, who came to Bedrock to perform a concert.
Chitty-Chitty-Bang-Bang, the magical car created by James Bond author Ian Fleming, was inspired by a series of racing cars built by Count Louis Zborowski, nicknamed Chitty Bang Bang.
In 1969, Senator Ted Kennedy’s car went off a bridge on Chappaquiddick Island, drowning the young woman who was his passenger; the scandal almost ended his political career.
Weaver’s brother was famed NBC president Pat Weaver, making Doodles’ niece Sigourney Weaver.
Eccentric singer Michael Jackson’s well-known fondness for children exploded into scandal when a 13-year-old boy accused the singer of molesting him in 1993.
Unsurprisingly, the “candy kids” who sell door-to-door in the summer are a scam, frequently exploiting runaways who are often abused.
Aleve is an OTC painkiller that bills itself as the solution for minor arthritis pain.
Comedian Imogene Coca is best known for playing opposite Sid Caesar on Your Show of Shows.
A moiré pattern occurs when two sets of parallel lines overlap and produce a kind of visual feedback.
The Dodge Neon was an economy car made by Chrysler. It ranked 9th for highest rate of driver deaths from 2002-05.
The predecessor to the Senate Select Committee on Ethics was created the year after this movie was released; the actual Ethics Committee was born in 1977.
Cathy tried on bathing suits for 34 years until the strip finally ended its run in 2010.
Despite critics’ almost universal hatred for Adam Sandler, his films have grossed more than $2.5 billion at the box office.
Forrest Gump starred Tom Hanks as a warm-hearted man with below-average intelligence. In the book the film is based on, Forrest is more of an autistic savant.
Rocky is the squeaky sidekick squirrel on The Bullwinkle Show, voiced by June Foray. Foray also voiced Cindy Lou Who, Lucifer the Cat in Cinderella, and many more.
Barney the dinosaur’s signature song on Barney & Friends begins, “I love you/You love me/We’re a happy family …”
Edith Prickley, played by Andrea Martin, was the leopard print-loving station manager on the Canadian comedy show SCTV.
In the film Fatal Attraction, Glenn Close breaks into Michael Douglas’s house after they have a one-night stand and kills his family’s pet rabbit, cooking it on the stove.
A line from the song “Hooked on a Feeling,” originally recorded by B.J. Thomas and famously covered by Blue Swede.
Actor Laurence Olivier appeared in many classic films, including Wuthering Heights, Rebecca, Pride and Prejudice, and Hamlet.
VSOP stands for “very superior old pale”; it is a grade of cognac indicating that the brandy has been stored in a cask for at least 4 years before being sold.
Mannix was a TV series starring Mike Connors as Joe Mannix, a private eye in LA. The show was known for its frequent shootouts, fistfights, and car chases.
After Elvis Presley and Ann-Margret made Viva Las Vegas together, the two were linked romantically for a brief time.
Michael Woodman (played by John Sylvester White) was first the assistant principal and later the principal on the sitcom Welcome Back, Kotter.
Elmer Fudd was also a Looney Tunes character, a hunter usually pitted against Bugs Bunny, although he appeared with Sylvester in a few cartoons.
Slim Jims are made from a mix of “beef head meat,” chicken, 30 spices, lactic acid, and liquid smoke.
An imitation of Frances Bavier as Aunt Bee, as seen in the ‘60s sitcom The Andy Griffith Show.
The most famous Isotoner glove in history is the one used to help acquit O.J. Simpson of the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ron Goldman.
Lovejoy was a BBC TV series about an antiques dealer (played by a young Ian McShane) who solved mysteries.
A line from the song “Smooth Operator” by Sade. It was the British band’s fourth single but their first U.S. hit.
The hugely popular comic strip “Garfield,” about a lazy, greedy cat, was raking in up to $1 billion a year in merchandising by 2004.
Super City was a building kit, similar to Lego, that was briefly sold in the late ‘60s. It was too complicated for most kids, so it didn’t last long.
That Girl was a TV series that starred Marlo Thomas as Ann Marie, an aspiring actress struggling to make it in New York City.
A line from the 1971 song “Poems, Prayers & Promises” by John Denver.
Male model Fabio, known for his flowing blond locks and muscular physique, became famous posing for romance novel covers and went on to act in movies and TV shows.
Also a reference to Luke 2:1 in the Bible: “And it came to pass in those days, that there went out a decree from Caesar Augustus that all the world should be taxed.”
In the black speech of Mordor, the One Ring’s inscription reads “Ash nazg durbatulûk, ash nazg gimbatul,ash nazg thrakatulûk agh burzum-ishi krimpatul.”
Sopapilla is derived from the word Xopaipa, meaning bread soaked in oil: deep-fried rounds of bread dough, which can be served either sweet or savory.
She sang two songs in the episode, but “Twitch, twitch” is actually from “The Bedrock Twitch,” which Fred sang in the third season episode “The Twitch.”
The Burning Bed is a nonfiction book about a woman who killed her abusive husband by setting him on fire while he was asleep. It was made into a TV movie starring Farrah Fawcett.
Sylvester was most often paired with the much smarter Tweety Bird.
Doodles Weaver played Professor Feetlebaum on the old Spike Jones radio program and appeared in a series of silent comedy shorts for TV in the ‘60s.
Scenes for Young Actors is a book featuring short scenes taken from plays like Uncle Vanya and The Crucible, meant for use in acting classes.
A paraphrase of the opening voiceover from Francis Ford Coppola’s film Apocalypse Now, spoken by Martin Sheen.
Sweeney Todd is a homicidal barber who became famous as a villain in Victorian penny dreadfuls; he is best known now through Stephen Sondheim’s musical Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.
Until his death, Presley sent guitar-shaped floral arrangements to Ann-Margret whenever she opened a new Vegas show.
Let us know if we missed any references!
A reference to MST3K Episode 522, Teen-Age Crime Wave.
Journalist Bob Woodward won the Pulitzer Prize for helping to uncover the Watergate scandal for the Washington Post, which ultimately forced President Richard Nixon to resign.
In the film It’s a Wonderful Life, Donna Reed, playing Mary Hatch, loses her bathrobe and hides briefly in a hydrangea bush.
“Viva Las Vegas” is the theme song to the 1964 Elvis Presley and Ann-Margret film of the same name, about a race-car driver in Vegas.
The original title of Cher’s #1 hit song “Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves” was “Gypsys, Tramps and White Trash.”
Brought to you by the Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
Colonel Harland Sanders was the man who, in 1940, came up with the famous “original recipe” and founded Kentucky Fried Chicken. His title was purely honorary.
A line from the hit 1981 Olivia Newton John song “Physical.”
Sue Lyon was an actress and sex symbol in the ‘60s who got her start playing Lolita in the 1962 film of the same name.
Flower Drum Song is a Rodgers & Hammerstein musical about intergenerational conflict and romance in San Francisco’s Chinatown.
Montrachet vineyards were first planted in the Middle Ages. Unlike other vineyards in Burgundy, they produce mostly chardonnays—some of the most expensive in the world.
This line is one of the catchphrases from the Jim Carrey movie Ace Ventura: Pet Detective.
Three WB shorts starring Sylvester the Cat won Oscars—a record for a featured Looney Tunes character.
In the ‘80s, Taco Bell sold fried, cinnamon sugar-dusted tortilla chips called Cinnamon Crispas—basically their version of churros.
“Cathy” was a comic strip by Cathy Guisewite about a young woman who is perpetually overweight and eternally frazzled.
Gladys and Abner Kravitz were the nosy neighbors on Bewitched, while The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles featured Jones as an old man, a boy of 10, and a young man in his late teens.
Johnny Hodges was a renowned alto saxophone player who played in Duke Ellington’s orchestra for 40 years.
Skier Suzy Chaffee starred in an ad campaign for ChapStick lip balm in the ‘70s in which she was dubbed “Suzy Chapstick.”
The film I Am a Fugitive from a Chain Gang starred Paul Muni as an wrongfully convicted man who escapes a brutal chain gang.
The Chicago Cubs were notorious losers, having failed to play in a World Series since 1945 and having failed to win one since 1908.
Probably a reference to the famous shouted first line of the song “Fire” by The Crazy World of Arthur Brown: “I am the god of hellfire!”
Chad Stuart and Jeremy Clyde were a dreamy folk-rock duo popular in the ‘60s, with hits such as “A Summer Song” and “Willow Weep for Me.”
Folk singer Woody Guthrie rode the trains for a time during the Depression, and wrote several songs romanticizing the lifestyle.
A line from “Papa Don’t Preach,” from Madonna’s True Blue album. Hard as it is to believe now, the song sparked some controversy on the grounds that it endorsed teen pregnancy.
Rolfing, also known as structural integration, is a form of deep massage whose advocates say can heal all sorts of health problems.
Kitten With A Whip: Fully annotated by The Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
Doodles’ real name is Winstead Sheffield Glenndenning Dixon Weaver.
One view of Revelations is that the “mark of the beast” referred to the image of the Roman emperor on coins; the Greek word charagma also meant a mark stamped on a coin.
Samantha Stephens, played by Elizabeth Montgomery, was the housewife/witch on the TV series Bewitched.
“L’Eggo my Eggo” is a longtime ad slogan for Eggo frozen waffles, used from 1972-2011 and revived in 2014.

Various states are excluded from TV offers. Pre-‘90s, Nebraska was often out of luck: the Strategic Air Command was there, so it was a good place for call centers, and in-state contests were verboten.
A line from the 1965 James Brown song “I Got You (I Feel Good).”

“Please, God, I’m Only 17!” is a cautionary essay about the dangers of reckless driving. It was originally written by IRS employee John Berrio and frequently ran in Dear Abby and Ann Landers’ columns.
Old Gringo is a film about a schoolteacher caught up in the Mexican Revolution. It starred Jane Fonda and Gregory Peck.
Endora (played by a flamboyant Agnes Moorehead) was Darrin Stephens’s impossible mother-in-law on the TV sitcom Bewitched.
A line from the song “Bloody Well Right” by Supertramp.
Powwow Highway is a 1989 film about two Cheyenne on a road trip to get a relative out of jail. It was based on the novel by David Seals.
In 1987, Roxanne Pulitzer published a tell-all book called The Prize Pulitzer: The Roxanne Pulitzer Story after her bitter divorce from Pulitzer heir Peter.
The leonine Dee Snider was the lead singer for the heavy metal band Twisted Sister, known chiefly for its song “We’re Not Gonna Take It.”
A line from the song “Jesus Loves Me.” The lyrics were taken from an 1860 poem by Anna Bartlett Warner; the tune was written two years later by William Bradbury.
Every year in the running of the bulls in Pamplona, Spain, between 50-100 people are injured; however, between 1910 and 2016, only 15 were killed.
On the ‘60s TV show Batman, punches and kicks during fight scenes were often obscured by cartoonish words such as “Boff!”, “Pow!”, and “Zap!”—thus averting criticism that the show was too violent.
Annie Green Springs was a brand of cheap wine—similar to Boone’s Farm—that was popular in the ‘70s.
Charades has its roots in a French riddle game of the 18th century, which turned into the familiar parlor game in the 19th century.
The National Hobo Convention has been held every August in Britt, Iowa, since 1900. It attracts about 20,000 tourists, and about 75 actual hobos.
A line from the song “Happy Trails,” which was the theme song for Dale Evans and Roy Rogers; it was written by Evans.
When Motel 6 was founded in 1962, the room rate per night was $6—the equivalent of $47 today. You can still get a room there for about $50. Well done.
An imitation of the typically lustful way Bob Hope would talk about his voluptuous co-stars.
The Dick Van Dyke Show is a ‘60s sitcom that famously featured the star tripping over an ottoman in the opening title sequence.
Russian chess player Boris Spassky famously lost the chess world championship to Bobby Fischer in 1972—the first time in 24 years a non-Soviet had won the title.
An imitation of actress Marilyn Monroe singing “Happy Birthday” to President John F. Kennedy in 1962. She famously had been sewn into her dress for the occasion.
An imitation of the opening narration of the TV series The Six Million Dollar Man.
Pampers inventor Victor Mills used his grandchildren as his test subjects in the ‘50s.
Señor Wences was a Spanish ventriloquist who made frequent appearances on The Ed Sullivan Show. He died in 1999 at the age of 103.
Public Image Ltd was an ‘80s rock group fronted by John Lydon (aka Johnny Rotten of the Sex Pistols).
A line from the Barbra Streisand song “Evergreen,” also known as the theme to her film A Star Is Born. It won an Oscar, a Grammy, and a Golden Globe.
A Hoppity Hop is a large rubber ball with a handle on the top, designed for kids to sit on and bounce. In Britain they are called space hoppers and in Italy, pon-pons.
Recipes for Chex mix began appearing on Chex cereal boxes as far back as 1952; recipes for “TV snack mixes” became popular as television became more widely available.
Historian Will Durant and his wife, Ariel, wrote the epic 11-volume The Story of Civilization. He was known for producing sweeping works focusing on the larger vistas of human history.
Cantinflas, aka Mario Moreno-Reyes, was a wildly popular Mexican comedian from the ‘30s through the ‘70s.
Get the inside scoop behind every reference in this episode.
From 1957-62, John Forsythe starred on a TV show called Bachelor Father, in which he played a rich California attorney raising his orphaned niece.
An imitation of the signature raspberry sound made by Edith Ann, comedian Lily Tomlin’s kid character.
A line from the song “Maria” from the musical The Sound of Music.
Paine Stewart was a pro golfer known for wearing knickers and a cloth cap on the course. He died in a plane crash in 1999.
A paraphrase of the poem “Comin’ Thro’ the Rye” by Robert Burns: “Gin a body meet a body/Coming thro' the rye,/Gin a body kiss a body,/Need a body cry?”
In the ‘70s-era ads for Mr. Microphone, a young man in a car used it to flirt with an unseen girl. The ads were parodied on the Simpsons episode “Radio Bart.”
Joe Pass was a well-known and respected jazz guitarist who worked with Ella Fitzgerald and Oscar Peterson.
“V.C.” is short for Viet Cong, the Western name for the rebel army opposing the government of South Vietnam during the Vietnam War. Their actual name was the National Liberation Front.
“Puff the Magic Dragon” is a song by Peter, Paul & Mary. Despite persistent rumors, the song’s authors have consistently denied that it is about smoking marijuana.
Stacy Keach is a tough-guy actor known for Mike Hammer and American History X. In the mid-‘80s he had some drug issues, including an arrest for cocaine possession.
Neil Bush, son of former President George H.W. Bush, is the black sheep of the family; in the late ‘80s and early ‘90s, the collapse of his savings and loan cost taxpayers roughly $1 billion.
A line from the theme song to the sitcom Happy Days. For the first two seasons it was only used in the closing credits; the opening credits used “Rock Around the Clock” by Bill Haley and His Comets.
The Pink Panther movies starred comedian Peter Sellers as the bumbling Inspector Jacques Clouseau. The famous theme, composed by Henry Mancini, won three Grammy Awards.
Weaver appeared in 90 films, including The Birds and the original The Nutty Professor.
A reference to Martin Luther King Jr.’s last speech, made on April 3, 1968. At the end, he talked about the possibility of dying; the next day he was murdered.
The US Senate Committee on Appropriations is the largest committee and, because it controls the pork, the most powerful.
A paraphrase of a line from Apocalypse Now: “Every minute I stay in this room, I get weaker, and every minute Charlie squats in the bush, he gets stronger.”
Bugsy Malone is a gangster movie musical in which all the mobsters are played by kids. It starred Scott Baio and Jodie Foster and was scored by Paul Williams, including the title song.
Mister Ed was a TV sitcom in the ‘60s about a talking horse.
Attorney Joel Hyatt founded Hyatt Legal Services, a low-cost law firm, and appeared in the firm’s TV ads, with the tagline, “I’m Joel Hyatt, and you have my word on it.”
In ‘70s ads for Right Guard deodorant, a man would open his bathroom cabinet, find his annoying neighbor on the other side, and plaintively call out for his wife.
A mai tai is a cocktail made from rum, orgeat syrup, curacao, and lime juice. The founder of Trader Vic’s, as well as his main rival, claims to have invented it.
Introduced in 1982, Diet Coke quickly became the best-selling diet soda in the US. Today it is the third most popular soda on the market, surpassed only by Coke and Pepsi.
Attractions that have actually existed at the Universal Studios theme parks: Creature From the Black Lagoon: The Musical and Kang and Kodos’ Twirl ‘n’ Hurl.
Composer Carl Stalling worked as the musical director for Warner Brothers’ Looney Tunes cartoons from 1936-58.
His little buddy, Gilligan, had only one name on the show. During a cast reunion, the show’s creator revealed his first name was actually Willy.
Standup comedian Stanley Myron Handelman was a fixture on TV variety shows and had a handful of acting roles in the ‘70s.
Talk show host David Letterman was dogged for years by a schizophrenic stalker named Margaret Ray who stole his car and broke into his house, claiming she was his wife and the mother of his child.
A paraphrase of the song “You’re the Top” by Cole Porter. It was the breakout song from the 1934 musical Anything Goes.
Did we somehow miss a reference? Let us know in the comments!
The Cubs ended the 108-year losing streak with their win in 2016!
The opening line to the song “The Sound of Music,” from the musical of the same name.
“Ding-dong, Avon calling” is an ad slogan for the direct-sales cosmetics company that dates to the ‘60s.
Ken Norton was a boxer in the ‘70s who famously fought Muhammad Ali 3 times. The third time Ali claimed he would KO Norton within 5 rounds; the fight lasted 15 before judges gave it to Ali.
“Irie” is a Jamaican word used by Rastafarians; it means “excellent” and is often used as a greeting.
Titled “Ruth,” this music was composed by Gerald Fried and used in romantic moments in the Star Trek episodes “Shore Leave” and “This Side of Paradise.”
The soft dome tweeter was invented in 1967 by audio pioneer Bill Hecht after people at audio shows kept prodding at his inflexible dome tweeters, often cracking them.
A representation of “Jarabe Tapatío,” better known as “The Mexican Hat Dance.”
Paraphrase of lines from the song “I Am a Rock” by Simon & Garfunkel.
When OSHA was created, about 14,000 US workers died on the job every year. Today that number has dropped to about 4,000.
Oscar Goldman (played by Richard Anderson) was Steve Austin’s boss on The Six Million Dollar Man.
Fleischmann’s is a brand of margarine made by Oscar Mayer.
A running gag on the TV show Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In had comedian Arte Johnson peer from a bush, dressed as a German soldier, to proclaim the previous skit “Very interesting, but stupid!”
"Thanks for caring" was the tag line for ads for the United Way, the well-known charity.
GATT and NAFTA are both free trade agreements. The tax reform bill is probably the one signed by Reagan in 1986, which dramatically lowered taxes for rich people.
Seven Crown is a brand of blended whiskey made by Seagram’s, known mostly for the drink 7 and 7: Seven Crown mixed with 7 Up.
The famous title sequence for Anatomy of a Murder, designed by Saul Bass, showed the names next to silhouetted body parts. Bass also did the titles for Psycho, which were very similar to these.
The Village Voice, like most alt-weeklies, has been hit hard by the newspaper crash; its current circulation is around 150,000, down from 250,000 at its peak.
An old-fashioned drawbridge leads to Sleeping Beauty’s castle and the entrance to Fantasyland at Disneyland. It does work, but has only been used twice in the park’s history.
Ethan Allen is an upscale chain of furniture stores founded in 1932. “For great American homes like yours” was a slogan used to sling Sears-brand paint in the ‘90s.
With annotations provided by The Annotated MST website.
Lines from the enigmatic song “Revolution 9,” from the Beatles’ White Album.
In 1994, when this episode aired, the Minnesota Twins’ win-loss record was a decent 53-60. In 2016 it stood at 59-103. Ouch.
Chucky is the homicidal doll in the Child’s Play horror flicks; he was voiced by Brad Dourif.
Director Russ Meyer made a string of films in the ‘60s and ‘70s starring women with extremely large breasts.
Jazz trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie’s trademark was a trumpet with the bell bent back at 45 degrees, the result of an accident in which someone fell on his instrument.
Pinchas Zukerman is an Israeli violinist and conductor.
For 44 years, comedian Jerry Lewis hosted an annual 21-hour Labor Day telethon for the Muscular Dystrophy Association, raising more than $2 billion for the cause.
An imitation of Jeffrey Tambor’s character, Hank Kingsley, saying his signature catchphrase on the ‘90s HBO sitcom The Larry Sanders Show.
In the Tennessee Williams play The Glass Menagerie, the fragile, isolated Laura refers to her old high-school acquaintance Jim as her “gentleman caller.”
Clark Bars are a type of candy bar sold as far back as 1917. They are manufactured by Necco.
Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus is a famous self-help book by counselor John Gray, about the difficulties men and women have in maintaining relationships.
Femiron is a dietary supplement for women.
Jody and Buffy were the youngest kids on the TV show Family Affair. (The third child was a teenage girl named Cissy.)
In the 1992 presidential debates, candidate Ross Perot came out against NAFTA, saying, “There will be a giant sucking sound [as jobs go] south.”
A reference to the song by the same name, written by Hoagy Carmichael. The Cleftones recorded a popular cover version in 1961 that was used in American Graffiti.
The princess phone, a compact phone intended for the bedroom and marketed primarily to women, was introduced by Bell Telephones in 1959.
Singer Amy Grant revolutionized Christian pop music, and when she crossed over to straight pop in the ‘80s, it caused some controversy among her religious fans.
In “The Apple” episode of the original Star Trek TV series, surfer-type natives lived an idyllic life enslaved to a giant machine god, Vaal.
The Universal Product Code (aka the UPC code or the bar code) was introduced in 1974. The first item ever scanned was a pack of Juicy Fruit gum. It cost 67 cents.
Manx are a breed of cat originating on the Isle of Man. They are distinctive for lacking tails.
Billy Barty was a prolific actor who also crusaded for societal acceptance of little people, founding Little People of America to work toward that goal.
Nurse Ratched is the starched, repressive head nurse of the mental hospital in the Ken Kesey novel One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest. Louise Fletcher played her in the film version.
The Skipper’s actual name, rarely mentioned on Gilligan’s Island, was Jonas Grumby.
Chi-Chi’s is a chain of Mexican restaurants. The first location opened in Minneapolis in 1975, but there are no restaurants left in the US; there are still some in other countries.
Spoken in the tone of David Byrne as he sang “Same as it ever was!” in the 1981 Talking Heads hit song “Once in a Lifetime.”
A line from Act III, Scene 1 of the Shakespeare play Henry V: “Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more;/Or close the wall up with our English dead.”
Did we miss any references? Be sure to let us know in the comments!
Goober Pyle, played by George Lindsey, was a mechanic at Wally’s Filling Station on The Andy Griffith Show. His name was originally Goober Beasley, but was quickly changed to Pyle.
Comedian Jerry Lewis made an enormously popular series of slapstick comedies in the ‘50s and ‘60s, including The Bellboy and The Nutty Professor.
Banana seat bikes were children’s bikes with long seats and high handlebars, popular during the ‘60s. They were meant to look like “chopper” motorcycles.
A reference to MST3K Episode 101, The Crawling Eye.
The Gestapo, the secret police force of Nazi Germany, operated without judicial oversight and was subject to tremendous abuses of power. The word “gestapo” has come to mean any brutal police force.
Ventriloquist Shari Lewis starred in several children’s TV shows, beginning in the ‘50s. Her most famous puppet was Lamb Chop.
And now, we invite you to enjoy…the fully-annotated Kitten With A Whip!
A paraphrase of the talking apple tree’s line in the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz.
Penthouse Forum, now called Penthouse Letters, is a magazine in which readers write in explicit yet implausible letters about their “real-life” sexual experiences.
Medical Center was a TV drama set in a hospital in LA. It starred James Daly and Chad Everett.
Weaver appeared in dozens of TV shows, including Batman, Dragnet, The Monkees, and Fantasy Island.
Baby Bop is a small green dinosaur on the kiddie TV show Barney & Friends, which aired for many years on PBS.
Minneapolis musician Prince was one of the seminal musical talents of the ‘80s; his 1980 album was titled Dirty Mind.
Angular comedian Ruth Buzzi is best known for her appearances on the skit comedy TV show Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In.
“Bernice Bobs Her Hair” is a short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald about a young woman in the ‘20s learning to be more modern. It was made into a TV movie starring Shelley Duvall in 1976.
The tune for this couplet originated in an 1899 song called “At a Darktown Cakewalk.”
Thanks for watching this fully-annotated presentation of Kitten With A Whip!
Pebbles Flintstone was the young daughter who used a bone for a hair bow on the animated TV series The Flintstones.
